  1. Index

Elixir Language¶

This page shows examples of source files lexed by the same lexer, but rendered into HTML using different styles.

Some styles are richer than others in that they define more different token categories. Examples of such richer styles are the Default style, the Tango style and the Colorful style.

In all cases the lexer is the same, and the only difference is the colors defined by the styles.

Abap Style (abap)¶

To use this style just require the Makeup.Styles.HTML.StyleMap module and access the abap constant: 

# styles are macros that expand to constants
require Makeup.Styles.HTML.StyleMap
alias Makeup.Styles.HTML.StyleMap
StyleMap.abap_style

Or import the module and use the constant defined there: 

import Makeup.Styles.HTML.StyleMap
abap_style

nesting.exs¶ 

defmodule MyModule do
  @moduledoc """
  This is documentation for the module
  """
  
  @doc """
  This is documentation for the function
  """
  def f(x, y, z) do
    # Place the cursor over the delimiters (...), [...], etc.
    list = [x, y, z]
    tuple = {x, y, z}
    map = %{"x" => x, "y" => y, "z" => z}
    struct = %Long.Module.Name{x: x, y: y, z: y}
    << a::size(x), b::size(y), x::size(z) >> = "abcde"
    # Nested delimiters work too:
    nested = %{
      a: [x, y, z],
      b: {x, {x, y}, {x, {x, y}, {x, y, z, [x, y, z]}}},
      c: %Long.Module.Name{
        x: x,
        y: y,
        z: << a::size(x), b::size(y) >>
      }
    }
  end
  # That's all, folks!

  # The perfectly idiomatic Elixir code below is hard for mere humans to follow.
  # Maybe a little makeup can help you?
  # Place the cursor over the block keywords: do, else, catch, rescue after, end
  def g() do
    IO.inspect do
      "a"
    else
      IO.inspect do
        fn x -> x + 2 end # yes, it works on fn ... end too!
      else
        "b"
      catch
        if c do
          x
        else
          case y do
            1 -> if a do
                   b
                 else
                   c
                 end
            _ -> "Wow, we're deep now!"
          end
        end
      rescue
        "d"
      after
        "e"
      end
      "b"
    after
      "e"
    end
  end
end

sandbox.exs¶ 

# Numbers
0b0101011
1234 ; 0x1A ; 0xbeef ; 0763 ; 0o123
3.14 ; 5.0e21 ; 0.5e-12
100_000_000

# these are not valid numbers
0b012 ; 0xboar ; 0o888
0B01 ; 0XAF ; 0O123

# Characters
?a ; ?1 ; ?\n ; ?\s ; ?\c ; ? ; ?,
?\x{12} ; ?\x{abcd}
?\x34 ; ?\xF

# these show that only the first digit is part of the character
?\123 ; ?\12 ; ?\7

# Atoms
:this ; :that
:'complex atom'
:"with' \"\" 'quotes"
:" multi
 line ' \s \123 \xff
atom"
:... ; :<<>> ; :%{} ; :% ; :{}
:++; :--; :*; :~~~; :::
:% ; :. ; :<-

# Strings
"Hello world"
"Interspersed \x{ff} codes \7 \8 \65 \016 and \t\s\\s\z\+ \\ escapes"
"Quotes ' inside \" \123 the \"\" \xF \\xF string \\\" end"
"Multiline
   string"

# Char lists
'this is a list'
'escapes \' \t \\\''
'Multiline
    char
  list
'

# Binaries
<<1, 2, 3>>
<<"hello"::binary, c :: utf8, x::[4, unit(2)]>> = "helloâ„¢1"

# Sigils
~r/this + i\s "a" regex/
~R'this + i\s "a" regex too'
~w(hello #{ ["has" <> "123", '\c\d', "\123 interpol" | []] } world)s
~W(hello #{no "123" \c\d \123 interpol} world)s

~s{Escapes terminators \{ and \}, but no {balancing} # outside of sigil here }

~S"No escapes \s\t\n and no #{interpolation}"

:"atoms work #{"to" <> "o"}"

# Operators
x = 1 + 2.0 * 3
y = true and false; z = false or true
... = 144
... == !x && y || z
"hello" |> String.upcase |> String.downcase()
{^z, a} = {true, x}

# Free operators (added in 1.0.0)
p  ~>> f  = bind(p, f)
p1 ~>  p2 = pair_right(p1, p2)
p1 <~  p2 = pair_left(p1, p2)
p1 <~> p2 = pair_both(p1, p2)
p  |~> f  = map(p, f)
p1 <|> p2 = either(p1, p2)

# Lists, tuples, maps, keywords
[1, :a, 'hello'] ++ [2, 3]
[:head | [?t, ?a, ?i, ?l]]

{:one, 2.0, "three"}

[...: "this", <<>>: "is", %{}: "a keyword", %: "list", {}: "too"]
["this is an atom too": 1, "so is this": 2]
[option: "value", key: :word]
[++: "operator", ~~~: :&&&]

map = %{shortcut: "syntax"}
%{map | "update" => "me"}
%{ 12 => 13, :weird => ['thing'] }

# Comprehensions
for x <- 1..10, x < 5, do: {x, x}
pixels = "12345678"
for << <<r::4, g::4, b::4, a::size(4)>> <- pixels >> do
  [r, {g, %{"b" => a}}]
end

# String interpolation
"String #{inspect "interpolation"} is quite #{1+4+7} difficult"

# Identifiers
abc_123 = 1
_018OP = 2
A__0 == 3

# Modules
defmodule Long.Module.Name do
  @moduledoc "Simple module docstring"

  @doc """
  Multiline docstring
  "with quotes"
  and #{ inspect %{"interpolation" => "in" <> "action"} }
  now with #{ {:a, 'tuple'} }
  and #{ inspect {
      :tuple,
      %{ with: "nested #{ inspect %{ :interpolation => %{} } }" }
  } }
  """
  defstruct [:a, :name, :height]

  @doc ~S'''
  No #{interpolation} of any kind.
  \000 \x{ff}

  \n #{\x{ff}}
  '''
  def func(a, b \\ []), do: :ok

  # Function
  def f(x), do: x
  # Operator definition (don't highlight the `x`!)
  def x + y, do: nil
  def x * y, do: nil
  def x |> y, do: nil
  def x && y, do: nil
  def x || y, do: nil
  # Word operators
  def x and y, do: nil
  def x or y, do: nil
  def x in y, do: nil
  # unquote, quote and unquote_splicing:
  def quote(f)(x), do: nil
  def unquote(f)(x), do: nil
  def unquote_splicing(f)(x), do: nil
  # function name that starts with `quote`:
  def quote_me(x), do: nil

  @doc false
  def __before_compile__(_) do
    :ok
  end
end

# Structs
defmodule Second.Module do
  s = %Long.Module.Name{name: "Silly"}
  %Long.Module.Name{s | height: {192, :cm}}
  ".. #{%Long.Module.Name{s | height: {192, :cm}}} .."
end

# Types, pseudo-vars, attributes
defmodule M do
  @custom_attr :some_constant

  @before_compile Long.Module.Name

  @typedoc "This is a type"
  @type typ :: integer

  @typedoc """
  Another type
  """
  @opaque typtyp :: 1..10

  @spec func(typ, typtyp) :: :ok | :fail
  def func(a, b) do
    a || b || :ok || :fail
    Path.expand("..", __DIR__)
    IO.inspect __ENV__
    __NOTAPSEUDOVAR__ = 11
    __MODULE__.func(b, a)
  end

  defmacro m() do
    __CALLER__
  end
end

# Functions
anon = fn x, y, z ->
  fn(a, b, c) ->
    &(x + y - z * a / &1 + b + div(&2, c))
  end
end

&Set.put(&1, &2) ; & Set.put(&1, &2) ; &( Set.put(&1, &1) )

# Function calls
anon.(1, 2, 3); self; hd([1,2,3])
Kernel.spawn(fn -> :ok end)
IO.ANSI.black

# Control flow
if :this do
  :that
else
  :otherwise
end

pid = self
receive do
  {:EXIT, _} -> :done
  {^pid, :_} -> nil
  after 100 -> :no_luck
end

case __ENV__.line do
  x when is_integer(x) -> x
  x when x in 1..12 -> -x
end

cond do
  false -> "too bad"
  4 > 5 -> "oops"
  true -> nil
end

# Lexical scope modifiers
import Kernel, except: [spawn: 1, +: 2, /: 2, Unless: 2]
alias Long.Module.Name, as: N0men123_and4
use Bitwise

4 &&& 5
2 <<< 3

# Protocols
defprotocol Useless do
  def func1(this)
  def func2(that)
end

defimpl Useless, for: Atom do
end

# Exceptions
defmodule NotAnError do
  defexception [:message]
end

raise NotAnError, message: "This is not an error"

Algol Style (algol)¶

To use this style just require the Makeup.Styles.HTML.StyleMap module and access the algol constant: 

# styles are macros that expand to constants
require Makeup.Styles.HTML.StyleMap
alias Makeup.Styles.HTML.StyleMap
StyleMap.algol_style

Or import the module and use the constant defined there: 

import Makeup.Styles.HTML.StyleMap
algol_style

  defstruct [:a, :name, :height]

  @doc ~S'''
  No #{interpolation} of any kind.
  \000 \x{ff}

  \n #{\x{ff}}
  '''
  def func(a, b \\ []), do: :ok

  # Function
  def f(x), do: x
  # Operator definition (don't highlight the `x`!)
  def x + y, do: nil
  def x * y, do: nil
  def x |> y, do: nil
  def x && y, do: nil
  def x || y, do: nil
  # Word operators
  def x and y, do: nil
  def x or y, do: nil
  def x in y, do: nil
  # unquote, quote and unquote_splicing:
  def quote(f)(x), do: nil
  def unquote(f)(x), do: nil
  def unquote_splicing(f)(x), do: nil
  # function name that starts with `quote`:
  def quote_me(x), do: nil

  @doc false
  def __before_compile__(_) do
    :ok
  end
end

# Structs
defmodule Second.Module do
  s = %Long.Module.Name{name: "Silly"}
  %Long.Module.Name{s | height: {192, :cm}}
  ".. #{%Long.Module.Name{s | height: {192, :cm}}} .."
end

# Types, pseudo-vars, attributes
defmodule M do
  @custom_attr :some_constant

  @before_compile Long.Module.Name

  @typedoc "This is a type"
  @type typ :: integer

  @typedoc """
  Another type
  """
  @opaque typtyp :: 1..10

  @spec func(typ, typtyp) :: :ok | :fail
  def func(a, b) do
    a || b || :ok || :fail
    Path.expand("..", __DIR__)
    IO.inspect __ENV__
    __NOTAPSEUDOVAR__ = 11
    __MODULE__.func(b, a)
  end

  defmacro m() do
    __CALLER__
  end
end

# Functions
anon = fn x, y, z ->
  fn(a, b, c) ->
    &(x + y - z * a / &1 + b + div(&2, c))
  end
end

&Set.put(&1, &2) ; & Set.put(&1, &2) ; &( Set.put(&1, &1) )

# Function calls
anon.(1, 2, 3); self; hd([1,2,3])
Kernel.spawn(fn -> :ok end)
IO.ANSI.black

# Control flow
if :this do
  :that
else
  :otherwise
end

pid = self
receive do
  {:EXIT, _} -> :done
  {^pid, :_} -> nil
  after 100 -> :no_luck
end

case __ENV__.line do
  x when is_integer(x) -> x
  x when x in 1..12 -> -x
end

cond do
  false -> "too bad"
  4 > 5 -> "oops"
  true -> nil
end

# Lexical scope modifiers
import Kernel, except: [spawn: 1, +: 2, /: 2, Unless: 2]
alias Long.Module.Name, as: N0men123_and4
use Bitwise

4 &&& 5
2 <<< 3

# Protocols
defprotocol Useless do
  def func1(this)
  def func2(that)
end

defimpl Useless, for: Atom do
end

# Exceptions
defmodule NotAnError do
  defexception [:message]
end

raise NotAnError, message: "This is not an error"

Arduino Style (arduino)¶

To use this style just require the Makeup.Styles.HTML.StyleMap module and access the arduino constant: 

# styles are macros that expand to constants
require Makeup.Styles.HTML.StyleMap
alias Makeup.Styles.HTML.StyleMap
StyleMap.arduino_style

Or import the module and use the constant defined there: 

import Makeup.Styles.HTML.StyleMap
arduino_style

nesting.exs¶ 

defmodule MyModule do
  @moduledoc """
  This is documentation for the module
  """
  
  @doc """
  This is documentation for the function
  """
  def f(x, y, z) do
    # Place the cursor over the delimiters (...), [...], etc.
    list = [x, y, z]
    tuple = {x, y, z}
    map = %{"x" => x, "y" => y, "z" => z}
    struct = %Long.Module.Name{x: x, y: y, z: y}
    << a::size(x), b::size(y), x::size(z) >> = "abcde"
    # Nested delimiters work too:
    nested = %{
      a: [x, y, z],
      b: {x, {x, y}, {x, {x, y}, {x, y, z, [x, y, z]}}},
      c: %Long.Module.Name{
        x: x,
        y: y,
        z: << a::size(x), b::size(y) >>
      }
    }
  end
  # That's all, folks!

  # The perfectly idiomatic Elixir code below is hard for mere humans to follow.
  # Maybe a little makeup can help you?
  # Place the cursor over the block keywords: do, else, catch, rescue after, end
  def g() do
    IO.inspect do
      "a"
    else
      IO.inspect do
        fn x -> x + 2 end # yes, it works on fn ... end too!
      else
        "b"
      catch
        if c do
          x
        else
          case y do
            1 -> if a do
                   b
                 else
                   c
                 end
            _ -> "Wow, we're deep now!"
          end
        end
      rescue
        "d"
      after
        "e"
      end
      "b"
    after
      "e"
    end
  end
end

sandbox.exs¶ 

# Numbers
0b0101011
1234 ; 0x1A ; 0xbeef ; 0763 ; 0o123
3.14 ; 5.0e21 ; 0.5e-12
100_000_000

# these are not valid numbers
0b012 ; 0xboar ; 0o888
0B01 ; 0XAF ; 0O123

# Characters
?a ; ?1 ; ?\n ; ?\s ; ?\c ; ? ; ?,
?\x{12} ; ?\x{abcd}
?\x34 ; ?\xF

# these show that only the first digit is part of the character
?\123 ; ?\12 ; ?\7

# Atoms
:this ; :that
:'complex atom'
:"with' \"\" 'quotes"
:" multi
 line ' \s \123 \xff
atom"
:... ; :<<>> ; :%{} ; :% ; :{}
:++; :--; :*; :~~~; :::
:% ; :. ; :<-

# Strings
"Hello world"
"Interspersed \x{ff} codes \7 \8 \65 \016 and \t\s\\s\z\+ \\ escapes"
"Quotes ' inside \" \123 the \"\" \xF \\xF string \\\" end"
"Multiline
   string"

# Char lists
'this is a list'
'escapes \' \t \\\''
'Multiline
    char
  list
'

# Binaries
<<1, 2, 3>>
<<"hello"::binary, c :: utf8, x::[4, unit(2)]>> = "helloâ„¢1"

# Sigils
~r/this + i\s "a" regex/
~R'this + i\s "a" regex too'
~w(hello #{ ["has" <> "123", '\c\d', "\123 interpol" | []] } world)s
~W(hello #{no "123" \c\d \123 interpol} world)s

~s{Escapes terminators \{ and \}, but no {balancing} # outside of sigil here }

~S"No escapes \s\t\n and no #{interpolation}"

:"atoms work #{"to" <> "o"}"

# Operators
x = 1 + 2.0 * 3
y = true and false; z = false or true
... = 144
... == !x && y || z
"hello" |> String.upcase |> String.downcase()
{^z, a} = {true, x}

# Free operators (added in 1.0.0)
p  ~>> f  = bind(p, f)
p1 ~>  p2 = pair_right(p1, p2)
p1 <~  p2 = pair_left(p1, p2)
p1 <~> p2 = pair_both(p1, p2)
p  |~> f  = map(p, f)
p1 <|> p2 = either(p1, p2)

# Lists, tuples, maps, keywords
[1, :a, 'hello'] ++ [2, 3]
[:head | [?t, ?a, ?i, ?l]]

{:one, 2.0, "three"}

[...: "this", <<>>: "is", %{}: "a keyword", %: "list", {}: "too"]
["this is an atom too": 1, "so is this": 2]
[option: "value", key: :word]
[++: "operator", ~~~: :&&&]

map = %{shortcut: "syntax"}
%{map | "update" => "me"}
%{ 12 => 13, :weird => ['thing'] }

# Comprehensions
for x <- 1..10, x < 5, do: {x, x}
pixels = "12345678"
for << <<r::4, g::4, b::4, a::size(4)>> <- pixels >> do
  [r, {g, %{"b" => a}}]
end

# String interpolation
"String #{inspect "interpolation"} is quite #{1+4+7} difficult"

# Identifiers
abc_123 = 1
_018OP = 2
A__0 == 3

# Modules
defmodule Long.Module.Name do
  @moduledoc "Simple module docstring"

  @doc """
  Multiline docstring
  "with quotes"
  and #{ inspect %{"interpolation" => "in" <> "action"} }
  now with #{ {:a, 'tuple'} }
  and #{ inspect {
      :tuple,
      %{ with: "nested #{ inspect %{ :interpolation => %{} } }" }
  } }
  """
  defstruct [:a, :name, :height]

  @doc ~S'''
  No #{interpolation} of any kind.
  \000 \x{ff}

  \n #{\x{ff}}
  '''
  def func(a, b \\ []), do: :ok

  # Function
  def f(x), do: x
  # Operator definition (don't highlight the `x`!)
  def x + y, do: nil
  def x * y, do: nil
  def x |> y, do: nil
  def x && y, do: nil
  def x || y, do: nil
  # Word operators
  def x and y, do: nil
  def x or y, do: nil
  def x in y, do: nil
  # unquote, quote and unquote_splicing:
  def quote(f)(x), do: nil
  def unquote(f)(x), do: nil
  def unquote_splicing(f)(x), do: nil
  # function name that starts with `quote`:
  def quote_me(x), do: nil

  @doc false
  def __before_compile__(_) do
    :ok
  end
end

:"atoms work #{"to" <> "o"}"

# Operators
x = 1 + 2.0 * 3
y = true and false; z = false or true
... = 144
... == !x && y || z
"hello" |> String.upcase |> String.downcase()
{^z, a} = {true, x}

# Free operators (added in 1.0.0)
p  ~>> f  = bind(p, f)
p1 ~>  p2 = pair_right(p1, p2)
p1 <~  p2 = pair_left(p1, p2)
p1 <~> p2 = pair_both(p1, p2)
p  |~> f  = map(p, f)
p1 <|> p2 = either(p1, p2)

# Lists, tuples, maps, keywords
[1, :a, 'hello'] ++ [2, 3]
[:head | [?t, ?a, ?i, ?l]]

{:one, 2.0, "three"}

[...: "this", <<>>: "is", %{}: "a keyword", %: "list", {}: "too"]
["this is an atom too": 1, "so is this": 2]
[option: "value", key: :word]
[++: "operator", ~~~: :&&&]

map = %{shortcut: "syntax"}
%{map | "update" => "me"}
%{ 12 => 13, :weird => ['thing'] }

# Comprehensions
for x <- 1..10, x < 5, do: {x, x}
pixels = "12345678"
for << <<r::4, g::4, b::4, a::size(4)>> <- pixels >> do
  [r, {g, %{"b" => a}}]
end

# String interpolation
"String #{inspect "interpolation"} is quite #{1+4+7} difficult"

# Identifiers
abc_123 = 1
_018OP = 2
A__0 == 3

# Modules
defmodule Long.Module.Name do
  @moduledoc "Simple module docstring"

  @doc """
  Multiline docstring
  "with quotes"
  and #{ inspect %{"interpolation" => "in" <> "action"} }
  now with #{ {:a, 'tuple'} }
  and #{ inspect {
      :tuple,
      %{ with: "nested #{ inspect %{ :interpolation => %{} } }" }
  } }
  """
  defstruct [:a, :name, :height]

  @doc ~S'''
  No #{interpolation} of any kind.
  \000 \x{ff}

  \n #{\x{ff}}
  '''
  def func(a, b \\ []), do: :ok

  # Function
  def f(x), do: x
  # Operator definition (don't highlight the `x`!)
  def x + y, do: nil
  def x * y, do: nil
  def x |> y, do: nil
  def x && y, do: nil
  def x || y, do: nil
  # Word operators
  def x and y, do: nil
  def x or y, do: nil
  def x in y, do: nil
  # unquote, quote and unquote_splicing:
  def quote(f)(x), do: nil
  def unquote(f)(x), do: nil
  def unquote_splicing(f)(x), do: nil
  # function name that starts with `quote`:
  def quote_me(x), do: nil

  @doc false
  def __before_compile__(_) do
    :ok
  end
end

# Structs
defmodule Second.Module do
  s = %Long.Module.Name{name: "Silly"}
  %Long.Module.Name{s | height: {192, :cm}}
  ".. #{%Long.Module.Name{s | height: {192, :cm}}} .."
end

# Types, pseudo-vars, attributes
defmodule M do
  @custom_attr :some_constant

  @before_compile Long.Module.Name

  @typedoc "This is a type"
  @type typ :: integer

  @typedoc """
  Another type
  """
  @opaque typtyp :: 1..10

  @spec func(typ, typtyp) :: :ok | :fail
  def func(a, b) do
    a || b || :ok || :fail
    Path.expand("..", __DIR__)
    IO.inspect __ENV__
    __NOTAPSEUDOVAR__ = 11
    __MODULE__.func(b, a)
  end

  defmacro m() do
    __CALLER__
  end
end

# Functions
anon = fn x, y, z ->
  fn(a, b, c) ->
    &(x + y - z * a / &1 + b + div(&2, c))
  end
end

&Set.put(&1, &2) ; & Set.put(&1, &2) ; &( Set.put(&1, &1) )

# Function calls
anon.(1, 2, 3); self; hd([1,2,3])
Kernel.spawn(fn -> :ok end)
IO.ANSI.black

# Control flow
if :this do
  :that
else
  :otherwise
end

pid = self
receive do
  {:EXIT, _} -> :done
  {^pid, :_} -> nil
  after 100 -> :no_luck
end

case __ENV__.line do
  x when is_integer(x) -> x
  x when x in 1..12 -> -x
end

cond do
  false -> "too bad"
  4 > 5 -> "oops"
  true -> nil
end

# Lexical scope modifiers
import Kernel, except: [spawn: 1, +: 2, /: 2, Unless: 2]
alias Long.Module.Name, as: N0men123_and4
use Bitwise

4 &&& 5
2 <<< 3

# Protocols
defprotocol Useless do
  def func1(this)
  def func2(that)
end

defimpl Useless, for: Atom do
end

# Exceptions
defmodule NotAnError do
  defexception [:message]
end

raise NotAnError, message: "This is not an error"

BlackWhite Style (bw)¶

To use this style just require the Makeup.Styles.HTML.StyleMap module and access the bw constant: 

# styles are macros that expand to constants
require Makeup.Styles.HTML.StyleMap
alias Makeup.Styles.HTML.StyleMap
StyleMap.bw_style

Or import the module and use the constant defined there: 

import Makeup.Styles.HTML.StyleMap
bw_style

nesting.exs¶ 

defmodule MyModule do
  @moduledoc """
  This is documentation for the module
  """
  
  @doc """
  This is documentation for the function
  """
  def f(x, y, z) do
    # Place the cursor over the delimiters (...), [...], etc.
    list = [x, y, z]
    tuple = {x, y, z}
    map = %{"x" => x, "y" => y, "z" => z}
    struct = %Long.Module.Name{x: x, y: y, z: y}
    << a::size(x), b::size(y), x::size(z) >> = "abcde"
    # Nested delimiters work too:
    nested = %{
      a: [x, y, z],
      b: {x, {x, y}, {x, {x, y}, {x, y, z, [x, y, z]}}},
      c: %Long.Module.Name{
        x: x,
        y: y,
        z: << a::size(x), b::size(y) >>
      }
    }
  end
  # That's all, folks!

  # The perfectly idiomatic Elixir code below is hard for mere humans to follow.
  # Maybe a little makeup can help you?
  # Place the cursor over the block keywords: do, else, catch, rescue after, end
  def g() do
    IO.inspect do
      "a"
    else
      IO.inspect do
        fn x -> x + 2 end # yes, it works on fn ... end too!
      else
        "b"
      catch
        if c do
          x
        else
          case y do
            1 -> if a do
                   b
                 else
                   c
                 end
            _ -> "Wow, we're deep now!"
          end
        end
      rescue
        "d"
      after
        "e"
      end
      "b"
    after
      "e"
    end
  end
end

sandbox.exs¶ 

# Numbers
0b0101011
1234 ; 0x1A ; 0xbeef ; 0763 ; 0o123
3.14 ; 5.0e21 ; 0.5e-12
100_000_000

# these are not valid numbers
0b012 ; 0xboar ; 0o888
0B01 ; 0XAF ; 0O123

# Characters
?a ; ?1 ; ?\n ; ?\s ; ?\c ; ? ; ?,
?\x{12} ; ?\x{abcd}
?\x34 ; ?\xF

# these show that only the first digit is part of the character
?\123 ; ?\12 ; ?\7

:'complex atom'
:"with' \"\" 'quotes"
:" multi

atom"

"Quotes ' inside \" \123 the \"\" \xF \\xF string \\\" end"
"Multiline
   string"

'Multiline
    char
  list
'

~R'this + i\s "a" regex too'
~w(hello #{ ["has" <> "123", '\c\d', "\123 interpol" | []] } world)s
~W(hello #{no "123" \c\d \123 interpol} world)s

        fn x -> x + 2 end # yes, it works on fn ... end too!
      else
        "b"
      catch
        if c do
          x
        else
          case y do
            1 -> if a do
                   b
                 else
                   c
                 end
            _ -> "Wow, we're deep now!"
          end
        end
      rescue
        "d"
      after
        "e"
      end
      "b"
    after
      "e"
    end
  end
end

sandbox.exs¶ 

# Numbers
0b0101011
1234 ; 0x1A ; 0xbeef ; 0763 ; 0o123
3.14 ; 5.0e21 ; 0.5e-12
100_000_000

# these are not valid numbers
0b012 ; 0xboar ; 0o888
0B01 ; 0XAF ; 0O123

# Characters
?a ; ?1 ; ?\n ; ?\s ; ?\c ; ? ; ?,
?\x{12} ; ?\x{abcd}
?\x34 ; ?\xF

# these show that only the first digit is part of the character
?\123 ; ?\12 ; ?\7

# Atoms
:this ; :that
:'complex atom'
:"with' \"\" 'quotes"
:" multi
 line ' \s \123 \xff
atom"
:... ; :<<>> ; :%{} ; :% ; :{}
:++; :--; :*; :~~~; :::
:% ; :. ; :<-

# Strings
"Hello world"
"Interspersed \x{ff} codes \7 \8 \65 \016 and \t\s\\s\z\+ \\ escapes"
"Quotes ' inside \" \123 the \"\" \xF \\xF string \\\" end"
"Multiline
   string"

# Char lists
'this is a list'
'escapes \' \t \\\''
'Multiline
    char
  list
'

# Binaries
<<1, 2, 3>>
<<"hello"::binary, c :: utf8, x::[4, unit(2)]>> = "helloâ„¢1"

# Sigils
~r/this + i\s "a" regex/
~R'this + i\s "a" regex too'
~w(hello #{ ["has" <> "123", '\c\d', "\123 interpol" | []] } world)s
~W(hello #{no "123" \c\d \123 interpol} world)s

~s{Escapes terminators \{ and \}, but no {balancing} # outside of sigil here }

~S"No escapes \s\t\n and no #{interpolation}"

:"atoms work #{"to" <> "o"}"

# Operators
x = 1 + 2.0 * 3
y = true and false; z = false or true
... = 144
... == !x && y || z
"hello" |> String.upcase |> String.downcase()
{^z, a} = {true, x}

# Free operators (added in 1.0.0)
p  ~>> f  = bind(p, f)
p1 ~>  p2 = pair_right(p1, p2)
p1 <~  p2 = pair_left(p1, p2)
p1 <~> p2 = pair_both(p1, p2)
p  |~> f  = map(p, f)
p1 <|> p2 = either(p1, p2)

# Lists, tuples, maps, keywords
[1, :a, 'hello'] ++ [2, 3]
[:head | [?t, ?a, ?i, ?l]]

{:one, 2.0, "three"}

[...: "this", <<>>: "is", %{}: "a keyword", %: "list", {}: "too"]
["this is an atom too": 1, "so is this": 2]
[option: "value", key: :word]
[++: "operator", ~~~: :&&&]

map = %{shortcut: "syntax"}
%{map | "update" => "me"}
%{ 12 => 13, :weird => ['thing'] }

# Comprehensions
for x <- 1..10, x < 5, do: {x, x}
pixels = "12345678"
for << <<r::4, g::4, b::4, a::size(4)>> <- pixels >> do
  [r, {g, %{"b" => a}}]
end

# String interpolation
"String #{inspect "interpolation"} is quite #{1+4+7} difficult"

# Identifiers
abc_123 = 1
_018OP = 2
A__0 == 3

# Modules
defmodule Long.Module.Name do
  @moduledoc "Simple module docstring"

  @doc """
  Multiline docstring
  "with quotes"
  and #{ inspect %{"interpolation" => "in" <> "action"} }
  now with #{ {:a, 'tuple'} }
  and #{ inspect {
      :tuple,
      %{ with: "nested #{ inspect %{ :interpolation => %{} } }" }
  } }
  """
  defstruct [:a, :name, :height]

  @doc ~S'''
  No #{interpolation} of any kind.
  \000 \x{ff}

  \n #{\x{ff}}
  '''
  def func(a, b \\ []), do: :ok

  # Function
  def f(x), do: x
  # Operator definition (don't highlight the `x`!)
  def x + y, do: nil
  def x * y, do: nil
  def x |> y, do: nil
  def x && y, do: nil
  def x || y, do: nil
  # Word operators
  def x and y, do: nil
  def x or y, do: nil
  def x in y, do: nil
  # unquote, quote and unquote_splicing:
  def quote(f)(x), do: nil
  def unquote(f)(x), do: nil
  def unquote_splicing(f)(x), do: nil
  # function name that starts with `quote`:
  def quote_me(x), do: nil

  @doc false
  def __before_compile__(_) do
    :ok
  end
end

# Structs
defmodule Second.Module do
  s = %Long.Module.Name{name: "Silly"}
  %Long.Module.Name{s | height: {192, :cm}}
  ".. #{%Long.Module.Name{s | height: {192, :cm}}} .."
end

# Types, pseudo-vars, attributes
defmodule M do
  @custom_attr :some_constant

  @before_compile Long.Module.Name

  @typedoc "This is a type"
  @type typ :: integer

  @typedoc """
  Another type
  """
  @opaque typtyp :: 1..10

  @spec func(typ, typtyp) :: :ok | :fail
  def func(a, b) do
    a || b || :ok || :fail
    Path.expand("..", __DIR__)
    IO.inspect __ENV__
    __NOTAPSEUDOVAR__ = 11
    __MODULE__.func(b, a)
  end

  defmacro m() do
    __CALLER__
  end
end

# Functions
anon = fn x, y, z ->
  fn(a, b, c) ->
    &(x + y - z * a / &1 + b + div(&2, c))
  end
end

&Set.put(&1, &2) ; & Set.put(&1, &2) ; &( Set.put(&1, &1) )

# Function calls
anon.(1, 2, 3); self; hd([1,2,3])
Kernel.spawn(fn -> :ok end)
IO.ANSI.black

# Control flow
if :this do
  :that
else
  :otherwise
end

pid = self
receive do
  {:EXIT, _} -> :done
  {^pid, :_} -> nil
  after 100 -> :no_luck
end

case __ENV__.line do
  x when is_integer(x) -> x
  x when x in 1..12 -> -x
end

cond do
  false -> "too bad"
  4 > 5 -> "oops"
  true -> nil
end

# Lexical scope modifiers
import Kernel, except: [spawn: 1, +: 2, /: 2, Unless: 2]
alias Long.Module.Name, as: N0men123_and4
use Bitwise

4 &&& 5
2 <<< 3

# Protocols
defprotocol Useless do
  def func1(this)
  def func2(that)
end

defimpl Useless, for: Atom do
end

# Exceptions
defmodule NotAnError do
  defexception [:message]
end

raise NotAnError, message: "This is not an error"

Emacs Style (emacs)¶

To use this style just require the Makeup.Styles.HTML.StyleMap module and access the emacs constant: 

# styles are macros that expand to constants
require Makeup.Styles.HTML.StyleMap
alias Makeup.Styles.HTML.StyleMap
StyleMap.emacs_style

Or import the module and use the constant defined there: 

import Makeup.Styles.HTML.StyleMap
emacs_style

nesting.exs¶ 

defmodule MyModule do
  @moduledoc """
  This is documentation for the module
  """
  
  @doc """
  This is documentation for the function
  """
  def f(x, y, z) do
    # Place the cursor over the delimiters (...), [...], etc.
    list = [x, y, z]
    tuple = {x, y, z}
    map = %{"x" => x, "y" => y, "z" => z}
    struct = %Long.Module.Name{x: x, y: y, z: y}
    << a::size(x), b::size(y), x::size(z) >> = "abcde"
    # Nested delimiters work too:
    nested = %{
      a: [x, y, z],
      b: {x, {x, y}, {x, {x, y}, {x, y, z, [x, y, z]}}},
      c: %Long.Module.Name{
        x: x,
        y: y,
        z: << a::size(x), b::size(y) >>
      }
    }
  end
  # That's all, folks!

  # The perfectly idiomatic Elixir code below is hard for mere humans to follow.
  # Maybe a little makeup can help you?
  # Place the cursor over the block keywords: do, else, catch, rescue after, end
  def g() do
    IO.inspect do
      "a"
    else
      IO.inspect do
        fn x -> x + 2 end # yes, it works on fn ... end too!
      else
        "b"
      catch
        if c do
          x
        else
          case y do
            1 -> if a do
                   b
                 else
                   c
                 end
            _ -> "Wow, we're deep now!"
          end
        end
      rescue
        "d"
      after
        "e"
      end
      "b"
    after
      "e"
    end
  end
end

alias Long.Module.Name, as: N0men123_and4
use Bitwise

4 &&& 5
2 <<< 3

# Protocols
defprotocol Useless do
  def func1(this)
  def func2(that)
end

defimpl Useless, for: Atom do
end

# Exceptions
defmodule NotAnError do
  defexception [:message]
end

raise NotAnError, message: "This is not an error"

Fruity Style (fruity)¶

To use this style just require the Makeup.Styles.HTML.StyleMap module and access the fruity constant: 

# styles are macros that expand to constants
require Makeup.Styles.HTML.StyleMap
alias Makeup.Styles.HTML.StyleMap
StyleMap.fruity_style

Or import the module and use the constant defined there: 

import Makeup.Styles.HTML.StyleMap
fruity_style

nesting.exs¶ 

defmodule MyModule do
  @moduledoc """
  This is documentation for the module
  """
  
  @doc """
  This is documentation for the function
  """
  def f(x, y, z) do
    # Place the cursor over the delimiters (...), [...], etc.
    list = [x, y, z]
    tuple = {x, y, z}
    map = %{"x" => x, "y" => y, "z" => z}
    struct = %Long.Module.Name{x: x, y: y, z: y}
    << a::size(x), b::size(y), x::size(z) >> = "abcde"
    # Nested delimiters work too:
    nested = %{
      a: [x, y, z],
      b: {x, {x, y}, {x, {x, y}, {x, y, z, [x, y, z]}}},
      c: %Long.Module.Name{
        x: x,
        y: y,
        z: << a::size(x), b::size(y) >>
      }
    }
  end
  # That's all, folks!

  # The perfectly idiomatic Elixir code below is hard for mere humans to follow.
  # Maybe a little makeup can help you?
  # Place the cursor over the block keywords: do, else, catch, rescue after, end
  def g() do
    IO.inspect do
      "a"
    else
      IO.inspect do
        fn x -> x + 2 end # yes, it works on fn ... end too!
      else
        "b"
      catch
        if c do
          x
        else
          case y do
            1 -> if a do
                   b
                 else
                   c
                 end
            _ -> "Wow, we're deep now!"
          end
        end
      rescue
        "d"
      after
        "e"
      end
      "b"
    after
      "e"
    end
  end
end

sandbox.exs¶ 

# Numbers
0b0101011
1234 ; 0x1A ; 0xbeef ; 0763 ; 0o123
3.14 ; 5.0e21 ; 0.5e-12
100_000_000

# these are not valid numbers
0b012 ; 0xboar ; 0o888
0B01 ; 0XAF ; 0O123

# Characters
?a ; ?1 ; ?\n ; ?\s ; ?\c ; ? ; ?,
?\x{12} ; ?\x{abcd}
?\x34 ; ?\xF

# these show that only the first digit is part of the character
?\123 ; ?\12 ; ?\7

# Atoms
:this ; :that
:'complex atom'
:"with' \"\" 'quotes"
:" multi
 line ' \s \123 \xff
atom"
:... ; :<<>> ; :%{} ; :% ; :{}
:++; :--; :*; :~~~; :::
:% ; :. ; :<-

# Strings
"Hello world"
"Interspersed \x{ff} codes \7 \8 \65 \016 and \t\s\\s\z\+ \\ escapes"
"Quotes ' inside \" \123 the \"\" \xF \\xF string \\\" end"
"Multiline
   string"

# Char lists
'this is a list'
'escapes \' \t \\\''
'Multiline
    char
  list
'

# Binaries
<<1, 2, 3>>
<<"hello"::binary, c :: utf8, x::[4, unit(2)]>> = "helloâ„¢1"

# Sigils
~r/this + i\s "a" regex/
~R'this + i\s "a" regex too'
~w(hello #{ ["has" <> "123", '\c\d', "\123 interpol" | []] } world)s
~W(hello #{no "123" \c\d \123 interpol} world)s

~s{Escapes terminators \{ and \}, but no {balancing} # outside of sigil here }

~S"No escapes \s\t\n and no #{interpolation}"

:"atoms work #{"to" <> "o"}"

# Operators
x = 1 + 2.0 * 3
y = true and false; z = false or true
... = 144
... == !x && y || z
"hello" |> String.upcase |> String.downcase()
{^z, a} = {true, x}

# Free operators (added in 1.0.0)
p  ~>> f  = bind(p, f)
p1 ~>  p2 = pair_right(p1, p2)
p1 <~  p2 = pair_left(p1, p2)
p1 <~> p2 = pair_both(p1, p2)
p  |~> f  = map(p, f)
p1 <|> p2 = either(p1, p2)

# Lists, tuples, maps, keywords
[1, :a, 'hello'] ++ [2, 3]
[:head | [?t, ?a, ?i, ?l]]

{:one, 2.0, "three"}

[...: "this", <<>>: "is", %{}: "a keyword", %: "list", {}: "too"]
["this is an atom too": 1, "so is this": 2]
[option: "value", key: :word]
[++: "operator", ~~~: :&&&]

map = %{shortcut: "syntax"}
%{map | "update" => "me"}
%{ 12 => 13, :weird => ['thing'] }

# Comprehensions
for x <- 1..10, x < 5, do: {x, x}
pixels = "12345678"
for << <<r::4, g::4, b::4, a::size(4)>> <- pixels >> do
  [r, {g, %{"b" => a}}]
end

# String interpolation
"String #{inspect "interpolation"} is quite #{1+4+7} difficult"

# Identifiers
abc_123 = 1
_018OP = 2
A__0 == 3

# Modules
defmodule Long.Module.Name do
  @moduledoc "Simple module docstring"

  @doc """
  Multiline docstring
  "with quotes"
  and #{ inspect %{"interpolation" => "in" <> "action"} }
  now with #{ {:a, 'tuple'} }
  and #{ inspect {
      :tuple,
      %{ with: "nested #{ inspect %{ :interpolation => %{} } }" }
  } }
  """
  defstruct [:a, :name, :height]

  @doc ~S'''
  No #{interpolation} of any kind.
  \000 \x{ff}

  \n #{\x{ff}}
  '''
  def func(a, b \\ []), do: :ok

  # Function
  def f(x), do: x
  # Operator definition (don't highlight the `x`!)
  def x + y, do: nil
  def x * y, do: nil
  def x |> y, do: nil
  def x && y, do: nil
  def x || y, do: nil
  # Word operators
  def x and y, do: nil
  def x or y, do: nil
  def x in y, do: nil
  # unquote, quote and unquote_splicing:
  def quote(f)(x), do: nil
  def unquote(f)(x), do: nil
  def unquote_splicing(f)(x), do: nil
  # function name that starts with `quote`:
  def quote_me(x), do: nil

  @doc false
  def __before_compile__(_) do
    :ok
  end
end

# Structs
defmodule Second.Module do
  s = %Long.Module.Name{name: "Silly"}
  %Long.Module.Name{s | height: {192, :cm}}
  ".. #{%Long.Module.Name{s | height: {192, :cm}}} .."
end

# Types, pseudo-vars, attributes
defmodule M do
  @custom_attr :some_constant

  @before_compile Long.Module.Name

  @typedoc "This is a type"
  @type typ :: integer

  @typedoc """
  Another type
  """
  @opaque typtyp :: 1..10

  @spec func(typ, typtyp) :: :ok | :fail
  def func(a, b) do
    a || b || :ok || :fail
    Path.expand("..", __DIR__)
    IO.inspect __ENV__
    __NOTAPSEUDOVAR__ = 11
    __MODULE__.func(b, a)
  end

  defmacro m() do
    __CALLER__
  end
end

# Functions
anon = fn x, y, z ->
  fn(a, b, c) ->
    &(x + y - z * a / &1 + b + div(&2, c))
  end
end

&Set.put(&1, &2) ; & Set.put(&1, &2) ; &( Set.put(&1, &1) )

# Function calls
anon.(1, 2, 3); self; hd([1,2,3])
Kernel.spawn(fn -> :ok end)
IO.ANSI.black

# Control flow
if :this do
  :that
else
  :otherwise
end

pid = self
receive do
  {:EXIT, _} -> :done
  {^pid, :_} -> nil
  after 100 -> :no_luck
end

case __ENV__.line do
  x when is_integer(x) -> x
  x when x in 1..12 -> -x
end

cond do
  false -> "too bad"
  4 > 5 -> "oops"
  true -> nil
end

  def x in y, do: nil

  def quote(f)(x), do: nil
  def unquote(f)(x), do: nil
  def unquote_splicing(f)(x), do: nil
  # function name that starts with `quote`:
  def quote_me(x), do: nil

  @doc false
  def __before_compile__(_) do
    :ok
  end
end

# Structs
defmodule Second.Module do
  s = %Long.Module.Name{name: "Silly"}
  %Long.Module.Name{s | height: {192, :cm}}
  ".. #{%Long.Module.Name{s | height: {192, :cm}}} .."
end

# Types, pseudo-vars, attributes
defmodule M do
  @custom_attr :some_constant

  @before_compile Long.Module.Name

  @typedoc "This is a type"
  @type typ :: integer

  @typedoc """
  Another type
  """
  @opaque typtyp :: 1..10

  @spec func(typ, typtyp) :: :ok | :fail
  def func(a, b) do
    a || b || :ok || :fail
    Path.expand("..", __DIR__)
    IO.inspect __ENV__
    __NOTAPSEUDOVAR__ = 11
    __MODULE__.func(b, a)
  end

  defmacro m() do
    __CALLER__
  end
end

# Functions
anon = fn x, y, z ->
  fn(a, b, c) ->
    &(x + y - z * a / &1 + b + div(&2, c))
  end
end

&Set.put(&1, &2) ; & Set.put(&1, &2) ; &( Set.put(&1, &1) )

# Function calls
anon.(1, 2, 3); self; hd([1,2,3])
Kernel.spawn(fn -> :ok end)
IO.ANSI.black

# Control flow
if :this do
  :that
else
  :otherwise
end

pid = self
receive do
  {:EXIT, _} -> :done
  {^pid, :_} -> nil
  after 100 -> :no_luck
end

case __ENV__.line do
  x when is_integer(x) -> x
  x when x in 1..12 -> -x
end

cond do
  false -> "too bad"
  4 > 5 -> "oops"
  true -> nil
end

# Lexical scope modifiers
import Kernel, except: [spawn: 1, +: 2, /: 2, Unless: 2]
alias Long.Module.Name, as: N0men123_and4
use Bitwise

4 &&& 5
2 <<< 3

# Protocols
defprotocol Useless do
  def func1(this)
  def func2(that)
end

defimpl Useless, for: Atom do
end

# Exceptions
defmodule NotAnError do
  defexception [:message]
end

raise NotAnError, message: "This is not an error"

Manni Style (manni)¶

To use this style just require the Makeup.Styles.HTML.StyleMap module and access the manni constant: 

# styles are macros that expand to constants
require Makeup.Styles.HTML.StyleMap
alias Makeup.Styles.HTML.StyleMap
StyleMap.manni_style

Or import the module and use the constant defined there: 

import Makeup.Styles.HTML.StyleMap
manni_style

nesting.exs¶ 

defmodule MyModule do
  @moduledoc """
  This is documentation for the module
  """
  
  @doc """
  This is documentation for the function
  """
  def f(x, y, z) do
    # Place the cursor over the delimiters (...), [...], etc.
    list = [x, y, z]
    tuple = {x, y, z}
    map = %{"x" => x, "y" => y, "z" => z}
    struct = %Long.Module.Name{x: x, y: y, z: y}
    << a::size(x), b::size(y), x::size(z) >> = "abcde"
    # Nested delimiters work too:
    nested = %{
      a: [x, y, z],
      b: {x, {x, y}, {x, {x, y}, {x, y, z, [x, y, z]}}},
      c: %Long.Module.Name{
        x: x,
        y: y,
        z: << a::size(x), b::size(y) >>
      }
    }
  end
  # That's all, folks!

  # The perfectly idiomatic Elixir code below is hard for mere humans to follow.
  # Maybe a little makeup can help you?
  # Place the cursor over the block keywords: do, else, catch, rescue after, end
  def g() do
    IO.inspect do
      "a"
    else
      IO.inspect do
        fn x -> x + 2 end # yes, it works on fn ... end too!
      else
        "b"
      catch
        if c do
          x
        else
          case y do
            1 -> if a do
                   b
                 else
                   c
                 end
            _ -> "Wow, we're deep now!"
          end
        end
      rescue
        "d"
      after
        "e"
      end
      "b"
    after
      "e"
    end
  end
end

sandbox.exs¶ 

# Numbers
0b0101011
1234 ; 0x1A ; 0xbeef ; 0763 ; 0o123
3.14 ; 5.0e21 ; 0.5e-12
100_000_000

# these are not valid numbers
0b012 ; 0xboar ; 0o888
0B01 ; 0XAF ; 0O123

# Characters
?a ; ?1 ; ?\n ; ?\s ; ?\c ; ? ; ?,
?\x{12} ; ?\x{abcd}
?\x34 ; ?\xF

# these show that only the first digit is part of the character
?\123 ; ?\12 ; ?\7

# Atoms
:this ; :that
:'complex atom'
:"with' \"\" 'quotes"
:" multi
 line ' \s \123 \xff
atom"
:... ; :<<>> ; :%{} ; :% ; :{}
:++; :--; :*; :~~~; :::
:% ; :. ; :<-

# Strings
"Hello world"
"Interspersed \x{ff} codes \7 \8 \65 \016 and \t\s\\s\z\+ \\ escapes"
"Quotes ' inside \" \123 the \"\" \xF \\xF string \\\" end"
"Multiline
   string"

# Char lists
'this is a list'
'escapes \' \t \\\''
'Multiline
    char
  list
'

# Binaries
<<1, 2, 3>>
<<"hello"::binary, c :: utf8, x::[4, unit(2)]>> = "helloâ„¢1"

# Sigils
~r/this + i\s "a" regex/
~R'this + i\s "a" regex too'
~w(hello #{ ["has" <> "123", '\c\d', "\123 interpol" | []] } world)s
~W(hello #{no "123" \c\d \123 interpol} world)s

~s{Escapes terminators \{ and \}, but no {balancing} # outside of sigil here }

~S"No escapes \s\t\n and no #{interpolation}"

:"atoms work #{"to" <> "o"}"

# Operators
x = 1 + 2.0 * 3
y = true and false; z = false or true
... = 144
... == !x && y || z
"hello" |> String.upcase |> String.downcase()
{^z, a} = {true, x}

# Free operators (added in 1.0.0)
p  ~>> f  = bind(p, f)
p1 ~>  p2 = pair_right(p1, p2)
p1 <~  p2 = pair_left(p1, p2)
p1 <~> p2 = pair_both(p1, p2)
p  |~> f  = map(p, f)
p1 <|> p2 = either(p1, p2)

# Lists, tuples, maps, keywords
[1, :a, 'hello'] ++ [2, 3]
[:head | [?t, ?a, ?i, ?l]]

{:one, 2.0, "three"}

[...: "this", <<>>: "is", %{}: "a keyword", %: "list", {}: "too"]
["this is an atom too": 1, "so is this": 2]
[option: "value", key: :word]
[++: "operator", ~~~: :&&&]

map = %{shortcut: "syntax"}
%{map | "update" => "me"}
%{ 12 => 13, :weird => ['thing'] }

# Comprehensions
for x <- 1..10, x < 5, do: {x, x}
pixels = "12345678"
for << <<r::4, g::4, b::4, a::size(4)>> <- pixels >> do
  [r, {g, %{"b" => a}}]
end

# String interpolation
"String #{inspect "interpolation"} is quite #{1+4+7} difficult"

# Identifiers
abc_123 = 1
_018OP = 2
A__0 == 3

# Modules
defmodule Long.Module.Name do
  @moduledoc "Simple module docstring"

  @doc """
  Multiline docstring
  "with quotes"
  and #{ inspect %{"interpolation" => "in" <> "action"} }
  now with #{ {:a, 'tuple'} }
  and #{ inspect {
      :tuple,
      %{ with: "nested #{ inspect %{ :interpolation => %{} } }" }
  } }
  """
  defstruct [:a, :name, :height]

  @doc ~S'''
  No #{interpolation} of any kind.
  \000 \x{ff}

  \n #{\x{ff}}
  '''
  def func(a, b \\ []), do: :ok

  # Function
  def f(x), do: x
  # Operator definition (don't highlight the `x`!)
  def x + y, do: nil
  def x * y, do: nil
  def x |> y, do: nil
  def x && y, do: nil
  def x || y, do: nil
  # Word operators
  def x and y, do: nil
  def x or y, do: nil
  def x in y, do: nil
  # unquote, quote and unquote_splicing:
  def quote(f)(x), do: nil
  def unquote(f)(x), do: nil
  def unquote_splicing(f)(x), do: nil
  # function name that starts with `quote`:
  def quote_me(x), do: nil

  @doc false
  def __before_compile__(_) do
    :ok
  end
end

# Structs

  %Long.Module.Name{s | height: {192, :cm}}

end

p  |~> f  = map(p, f)
p1 <|> p2 = either(p1, p2)

# Lists, tuples, maps, keywords
[1, :a, 'hello'] ++ [2, 3]
[:head | [?t, ?a, ?i, ?l]]

{:one, 2.0, "three"}

[...: "this", <<>>: "is", %{}: "a keyword", %: "list", {}: "too"]
["this is an atom too": 1, "so is this": 2]
[option: "value", key: :word]
[++: "operator", ~~~: :&&&]

map = %{shortcut: "syntax"}
%{map | "update" => "me"}
%{ 12 => 13, :weird => ['thing'] }

# Comprehensions
for x <- 1..10, x < 5, do: {x, x}
pixels = "12345678"
for << <<r::4, g::4, b::4, a::size(4)>> <- pixels >> do
  [r, {g, %{"b" => a}}]
end

# String interpolation
"String #{inspect "interpolation"} is quite #{1+4+7} difficult"

# Identifiers
abc_123 = 1
_018OP = 2
A__0 == 3

# Modules
defmodule Long.Module.Name do
  @moduledoc "Simple module docstring"

  @doc """
  Multiline docstring
  "with quotes"
  and #{ inspect %{"interpolation" => "in" <> "action"} }
  now with #{ {:a, 'tuple'} }
  and #{ inspect {
      :tuple,
      %{ with: "nested #{ inspect %{ :interpolation => %{} } }" }
  } }
  """
  defstruct [:a, :name, :height]

  @doc ~S'''
  No #{interpolation} of any kind.
  \000 \x{ff}

  \n #{\x{ff}}
  '''
  def func(a, b \\ []), do: :ok

  # Function
  def f(x), do: x
  # Operator definition (don't highlight the `x`!)
  def x + y, do: nil
  def x * y, do: nil
  def x |> y, do: nil
  def x && y, do: nil
  def x || y, do: nil
  # Word operators
  def x and y, do: nil
  def x or y, do: nil
  def x in y, do: nil
  # unquote, quote and unquote_splicing:
  def quote(f)(x), do: nil
  def unquote(f)(x), do: nil
  def unquote_splicing(f)(x), do: nil
  # function name that starts with `quote`:
  def quote_me(x), do: nil

  @doc false
  def __before_compile__(_) do
    :ok
  end
end

# Structs
defmodule Second.Module do
  s = %Long.Module.Name{name: "Silly"}
  %Long.Module.Name{s | height: {192, :cm}}
  ".. #{%Long.Module.Name{s | height: {192, :cm}}} .."
end

# Types, pseudo-vars, attributes
defmodule M do
  @custom_attr :some_constant

  @before_compile Long.Module.Name

  @typedoc "This is a type"
  @type typ :: integer

  @typedoc """
  Another type
  """
  @opaque typtyp :: 1..10

  @spec func(typ, typtyp) :: :ok | :fail
  def func(a, b) do
    a || b || :ok || :fail
    Path.expand("..", __DIR__)
    IO.inspect __ENV__
    __NOTAPSEUDOVAR__ = 11
    __MODULE__.func(b, a)
  end

  defmacro m() do
    __CALLER__
  end
end

# Functions
anon = fn x, y, z ->
  fn(a, b, c) ->
    &(x + y - z * a / &1 + b + div(&2, c))
  end
end

&Set.put(&1, &2) ; & Set.put(&1, &2) ; &( Set.put(&1, &1) )

# Function calls
anon.(1, 2, 3); self; hd([1,2,3])
Kernel.spawn(fn -> :ok end)
IO.ANSI.black

# Control flow
if :this do
  :that
else
  :otherwise
end

pid = self
receive do
  {:EXIT, _} -> :done
  {^pid, :_} -> nil
  after 100 -> :no_luck
end

case __ENV__.line do
  x when is_integer(x) -> x
  x when x in 1..12 -> -x
end

cond do
  false -> "too bad"
  4 > 5 -> "oops"
  true -> nil
end

# Lexical scope modifiers
import Kernel, except: [spawn: 1, +: 2, /: 2, Unless: 2]
alias Long.Module.Name, as: N0men123_and4
use Bitwise

4 &&& 5
2 <<< 3

# Protocols
defprotocol Useless do
  def func1(this)
  def func2(that)
end

defimpl Useless, for: Atom do
end

# Exceptions
defmodule NotAnError do
  defexception [:message]
end

raise NotAnError, message: "This is not an error"

Native Style (native)¶

To use this style just require the Makeup.Styles.HTML.StyleMap module and access the native constant: 

# styles are macros that expand to constants
require Makeup.Styles.HTML.StyleMap
alias Makeup.Styles.HTML.StyleMap
StyleMap.native_style

Or import the module and use the constant defined there: 

import Makeup.Styles.HTML.StyleMap
native_style

nesting.exs¶ 

defmodule MyModule do
  @moduledoc """
  This is documentation for the module
  """
  
  @doc """
  This is documentation for the function
  """
  def f(x, y, z) do
    # Place the cursor over the delimiters (...), [...], etc.
    list = [x, y, z]
    tuple = {x, y, z}
    map = %{"x" => x, "y" => y, "z" => z}
    struct = %Long.Module.Name{x: x, y: y, z: y}
    << a::size(x), b::size(y), x::size(z) >> = "abcde"
    # Nested delimiters work too:
    nested = %{
      a: [x, y, z],
      b: {x, {x, y}, {x, {x, y}, {x, y, z, [x, y, z]}}},
      c: %Long.Module.Name{
        x: x,
        y: y,
        z: << a::size(x), b::size(y) >>
      }
    }
  end
  # That's all, folks!

  # The perfectly idiomatic Elixir code below is hard for mere humans to follow.
  # Maybe a little makeup can help you?
  # Place the cursor over the block keywords: do, else, catch, rescue after, end
  def g() do
    IO.inspect do
      "a"
    else
      IO.inspect do
        fn x -> x + 2 end # yes, it works on fn ... end too!
      else
        "b"
      catch
        if c do
          x
        else
          case y do
            1 -> if a do
                   b
                 else
                   c
                 end
            _ -> "Wow, we're deep now!"
          end
        end
      rescue
        "d"
      after
        "e"
      end
      "b"
    after
      "e"
    end
  end
end

sandbox.exs¶ 

# Numbers
0b0101011
1234 ; 0x1A ; 0xbeef ; 0763 ; 0o123
3.14 ; 5.0e21 ; 0.5e-12
100_000_000

# these are not valid numbers
0b012 ; 0xboar ; 0o888
0B01 ; 0XAF ; 0O123

# Characters
?a ; ?1 ; ?\n ; ?\s ; ?\c ; ? ; ?,
?\x{12} ; ?\x{abcd}
?\x34 ; ?\xF

# these show that only the first digit is part of the character
?\123 ; ?\12 ; ?\7

# Atoms
:this ; :that
:'complex atom'
:"with' \"\" 'quotes"
:" multi
 line ' \s \123 \xff
atom"
:... ; :<<>> ; :%{} ; :% ; :{}
:++; :--; :*; :~~~; :::
:% ; :. ; :<-

# Strings
"Hello world"
"Interspersed \x{ff} codes \7 \8 \65 \016 and \t\s\\s\z\+ \\ escapes"
"Quotes ' inside \" \123 the \"\" \xF \\xF string \\\" end"
"Multiline
   string"

# Char lists
'this is a list'
'escapes \' \t \\\''
'Multiline
    char
  list
'

# Binaries
<<1, 2, 3>>
<<"hello"::binary, c :: utf8, x::[4, unit(2)]>> = "helloâ„¢1"

# Sigils
~r/this + i\s "a" regex/
~R'this + i\s "a" regex too'
~w(hello #{ ["has" <> "123", '\c\d', "\123 interpol" | []] } world)s
~W(hello #{no "123" \c\d \123 interpol} world)s

~s{Escapes terminators \{ and \}, but no {balancing} # outside of sigil here }

~S"No escapes \s\t\n and no #{interpolation}"

:"atoms work #{"to" <> "o"}"

# Operators
x = 1 + 2.0 * 3
y = true and false; z = false or true
... = 144
... == !x && y || z
"hello" |> String.upcase |> String.downcase()
{^z, a} = {true, x}

# Free operators (added in 1.0.0)
p  ~>> f  = bind(p, f)
p1 ~>  p2 = pair_right(p1, p2)
p1 <~  p2 = pair_left(p1, p2)
p1 <~> p2 = pair_both(p1, p2)
p  |~> f  = map(p, f)
p1 <|> p2 = either(p1, p2)

# Lists, tuples, maps, keywords
[1, :a, 'hello'] ++ [2, 3]
[:head | [?t, ?a, ?i, ?l]]

{:one, 2.0, "three"}

[...: "this", <<>>: "is", %{}: "a keyword", %: "list", {}: "too"]
["this is an atom too": 1, "so is this": 2]
[option: "value", key: :word]
[++: "operator", ~~~: :&&&]

map = %{shortcut: "syntax"}
%{map | "update" => "me"}
%{ 12 => 13, :weird => ['thing'] }

pixels = "12345678"

  [r, {g, %{"b" => a}}]

1234 ; 0x1A ; 0xbeef ; 0763 ; 0o123
3.14 ; 5.0e21 ; 0.5e-12
100_000_000

# these are not valid numbers
0b012 ; 0xboar ; 0o888
0B01 ; 0XAF ; 0O123

# Characters
?a ; ?1 ; ?\n ; ?\s ; ?\c ; ? ; ?,
?\x{12} ; ?\x{abcd}
?\x34 ; ?\xF

# these show that only the first digit is part of the character
?\123 ; ?\12 ; ?\7

# Atoms
:this ; :that
:'complex atom'
:"with' \"\" 'quotes"
:" multi
 line ' \s \123 \xff
atom"
:... ; :<<>> ; :%{} ; :% ; :{}
:++; :--; :*; :~~~; :::
:% ; :. ; :<-

# Strings
"Hello world"
"Interspersed \x{ff} codes \7 \8 \65 \016 and \t\s\\s\z\+ \\ escapes"
"Quotes ' inside \" \123 the \"\" \xF \\xF string \\\" end"
"Multiline
   string"

# Char lists
'this is a list'
'escapes \' \t \\\''
'Multiline
    char
  list
'

# Binaries
<<1, 2, 3>>
<<"hello"::binary, c :: utf8, x::[4, unit(2)]>> = "helloâ„¢1"

# Sigils
~r/this + i\s "a" regex/
~R'this + i\s "a" regex too'
~w(hello #{ ["has" <> "123", '\c\d', "\123 interpol" | []] } world)s
~W(hello #{no "123" \c\d \123 interpol} world)s

~s{Escapes terminators \{ and \}, but no {balancing} # outside of sigil here }

~S"No escapes \s\t\n and no #{interpolation}"

:"atoms work #{"to" <> "o"}"

# Operators
x = 1 + 2.0 * 3
y = true and false; z = false or true
... = 144
... == !x && y || z
"hello" |> String.upcase |> String.downcase()
{^z, a} = {true, x}

# Free operators (added in 1.0.0)
p  ~>> f  = bind(p, f)
p1 ~>  p2 = pair_right(p1, p2)
p1 <~  p2 = pair_left(p1, p2)
p1 <~> p2 = pair_both(p1, p2)
p  |~> f  = map(p, f)
p1 <|> p2 = either(p1, p2)

# Lists, tuples, maps, keywords
[1, :a, 'hello'] ++ [2, 3]
[:head | [?t, ?a, ?i, ?l]]

{:one, 2.0, "three"}

[...: "this", <<>>: "is", %{}: "a keyword", %: "list", {}: "too"]
["this is an atom too": 1, "so is this": 2]
[option: "value", key: :word]
[++: "operator", ~~~: :&&&]

map = %{shortcut: "syntax"}
%{map | "update" => "me"}
%{ 12 => 13, :weird => ['thing'] }

# Comprehensions
for x <- 1..10, x < 5, do: {x, x}
pixels = "12345678"
for << <<r::4, g::4, b::4, a::size(4)>> <- pixels >> do
  [r, {g, %{"b" => a}}]
end

# String interpolation
"String #{inspect "interpolation"} is quite #{1+4+7} difficult"

# Identifiers
abc_123 = 1
_018OP = 2
A__0 == 3

# Modules
defmodule Long.Module.Name do
  @moduledoc "Simple module docstring"

  @doc """
  Multiline docstring
  "with quotes"
  and #{ inspect %{"interpolation" => "in" <> "action"} }
  now with #{ {:a, 'tuple'} }
  and #{ inspect {
      :tuple,
      %{ with: "nested #{ inspect %{ :interpolation => %{} } }" }
  } }
  """
  defstruct [:a, :name, :height]

  @doc ~S'''
  No #{interpolation} of any kind.
  \000 \x{ff}

  \n #{\x{ff}}
  '''
  def func(a, b \\ []), do: :ok

  # Function
  def f(x), do: x
  # Operator definition (don't highlight the `x`!)
  def x + y, do: nil
  def x * y, do: nil
  def x |> y, do: nil
  def x && y, do: nil
  def x || y, do: nil
  # Word operators
  def x and y, do: nil
  def x or y, do: nil
  def x in y, do: nil
  # unquote, quote and unquote_splicing:
  def quote(f)(x), do: nil
  def unquote(f)(x), do: nil
  def unquote_splicing(f)(x), do: nil
  # function name that starts with `quote`:
  def quote_me(x), do: nil

  @doc false
  def __before_compile__(_) do
    :ok
  end
end

# Structs
defmodule Second.Module do
  s = %Long.Module.Name{name: "Silly"}
  %Long.Module.Name{s | height: {192, :cm}}
  ".. #{%Long.Module.Name{s | height: {192, :cm}}} .."
end

# Types, pseudo-vars, attributes
defmodule M do
  @custom_attr :some_constant

  @before_compile Long.Module.Name

  @typedoc "This is a type"
  @type typ :: integer

  @typedoc """
  Another type
  """
  @opaque typtyp :: 1..10

  @spec func(typ, typtyp) :: :ok | :fail
  def func(a, b) do
    a || b || :ok || :fail
    Path.expand("..", __DIR__)
    IO.inspect __ENV__
    __NOTAPSEUDOVAR__ = 11
    __MODULE__.func(b, a)
  end

  defmacro m() do
    __CALLER__
  end
end

# Functions
anon = fn x, y, z ->
  fn(a, b, c) ->
    &(x + y - z * a / &1 + b + div(&2, c))
  end
end

&Set.put(&1, &2) ; & Set.put(&1, &2) ; &( Set.put(&1, &1) )

# Function calls
anon.(1, 2, 3); self; hd([1,2,3])
Kernel.spawn(fn -> :ok end)
IO.ANSI.black

# Control flow
if :this do
  :that
else
  :otherwise
end

pid = self
receive do
  {:EXIT, _} -> :done
  {^pid, :_} -> nil
  after 100 -> :no_luck
end

case __ENV__.line do
  x when is_integer(x) -> x
  x when x in 1..12 -> -x
end

cond do
  false -> "too bad"
  4 > 5 -> "oops"
  true -> nil
end

# Lexical scope modifiers
import Kernel, except: [spawn: 1, +: 2, /: 2, Unless: 2]
alias Long.Module.Name, as: N0men123_and4
use Bitwise

4 &&& 5
2 <<< 3

# Protocols
defprotocol Useless do
  def func1(this)
  def func2(that)
end

defimpl Useless, for: Atom do
end

# Exceptions
defmodule NotAnError do
  defexception [:message]
end

raise NotAnError, message: "This is not an error"

Pastie Style (pastie)¶

To use this style just require the Makeup.Styles.HTML.StyleMap module and access the pastie constant: 

# styles are macros that expand to constants
require Makeup.Styles.HTML.StyleMap
alias Makeup.Styles.HTML.StyleMap
StyleMap.pastie_style

Or import the module and use the constant defined there: 

import Makeup.Styles.HTML.StyleMap
pastie_style

nesting.exs¶ 

defmodule MyModule do
  @moduledoc """
  This is documentation for the module
  """
  
  @doc """
  This is documentation for the function
  """
  def f(x, y, z) do
    # Place the cursor over the delimiters (...), [...], etc.
    list = [x, y, z]
    tuple = {x, y, z}
    map = %{"x" => x, "y" => y, "z" => z}
    struct = %Long.Module.Name{x: x, y: y, z: y}
    << a::size(x), b::size(y), x::size(z) >> = "abcde"
    # Nested delimiters work too:
    nested = %{
      a: [x, y, z],
      b: {x, {x, y}, {x, {x, y}, {x, y, z, [x, y, z]}}},
      c: %Long.Module.Name{
        x: x,
        y: y,
        z: << a::size(x), b::size(y) >>
      }
    }
  end
  # That's all, folks!

  # The perfectly idiomatic Elixir code below is hard for mere humans to follow.
  # Maybe a little makeup can help you?
  # Place the cursor over the block keywords: do, else, catch, rescue after, end
  def g() do
    IO.inspect do
      "a"
    else
      IO.inspect do
        fn x -> x + 2 end # yes, it works on fn ... end too!
      else
        "b"
      catch
        if c do
          x
        else
          case y do
            1 -> if a do
                   b
                 else
                   c
                 end
            _ -> "Wow, we're deep now!"
          end
        end
      rescue
        "d"
      after
        "e"
      end
      "b"
    after
      "e"
    end
  end
end

RainbowDash Style (rainbow_dash)¶

To use this style just require the Makeup.Styles.HTML.StyleMap module and access the rainbow_dash constant: 

# styles are macros that expand to constants
require Makeup.Styles.HTML.StyleMap
alias Makeup.Styles.HTML.StyleMap
StyleMap.rainbow_dash_style

Or import the module and use the constant defined there: 

import Makeup.Styles.HTML.StyleMap
rainbow_dash_style

nesting.exs¶ 

defmodule MyModule do
  @moduledoc """
  This is documentation for the module
  """
  
  @doc """
  This is documentation for the function
  """
  def f(x, y, z) do
    # Place the cursor over the delimiters (...), [...], etc.
    list = [x, y, z]
    tuple = {x, y, z}
    map = %{"x" => x, "y" => y, "z" => z}
    struct = %Long.Module.Name{x: x, y: y, z: y}
    << a::size(x), b::size(y), x::size(z) >> = "abcde"
    # Nested delimiters work too:
    nested = %{
      a: [x, y, z],
      b: {x, {x, y}, {x, {x, y}, {x, y, z, [x, y, z]}}},
      c: %Long.Module.Name{
        x: x,
        y: y,
        z: << a::size(x), b::size(y) >>
      }
    }
  end
  # That's all, folks!

  # The perfectly idiomatic Elixir code below is hard for mere humans to follow.
  # Maybe a little makeup can help you?
  # Place the cursor over the block keywords: do, else, catch, rescue after, end
  def g() do
    IO.inspect do
      "a"
    else
      IO.inspect do
        fn x -> x + 2 end # yes, it works on fn ... end too!
      else
        "b"
      catch
        if c do
          x
        else
          case y do
            1 -> if a do
                   b
                 else
                   c
                 end
            _ -> "Wow, we're deep now!"
          end
        end
      rescue
        "d"
      after
        "e"
      end
      "b"
    after
      "e"
    end
  end
end

sandbox.exs¶ 

# Numbers
0b0101011
1234 ; 0x1A ; 0xbeef ; 0763 ; 0o123
3.14 ; 5.0e21 ; 0.5e-12
100_000_000

# these are not valid numbers
0b012 ; 0xboar ; 0o888
0B01 ; 0XAF ; 0O123

# Characters
?a ; ?1 ; ?\n ; ?\s ; ?\c ; ? ; ?,
?\x{12} ; ?\x{abcd}
?\x34 ; ?\xF

# these show that only the first digit is part of the character
?\123 ; ?\12 ; ?\7

# Atoms
:this ; :that
:'complex atom'
:"with' \"\" 'quotes"
:" multi
 line ' \s \123 \xff
atom"
:... ; :<<>> ; :%{} ; :% ; :{}
:++; :--; :*; :~~~; :::
:% ; :. ; :<-

# Strings
"Hello world"
"Interspersed \x{ff} codes \7 \8 \65 \016 and \t\s\\s\z\+ \\ escapes"
"Quotes ' inside \" \123 the \"\" \xF \\xF string \\\" end"
"Multiline
   string"

# Char lists
'this is a list'
'escapes \' \t \\\''
'Multiline
    char
  list
'

# Binaries
<<1, 2, 3>>
<<"hello"::binary, c :: utf8, x::[4, unit(2)]>> = "helloâ„¢1"

# Sigils
~r/this + i\s "a" regex/
~R'this + i\s "a" regex too'
~w(hello #{ ["has" <> "123", '\c\d', "\123 interpol" | []] } world)s
~W(hello #{no "123" \c\d \123 interpol} world)s

~s{Escapes terminators \{ and \}, but no {balancing} # outside of sigil here }

~S"No escapes \s\t\n and no #{interpolation}"

:"atoms work #{"to" <> "o"}"

# Operators
x = 1 + 2.0 * 3
y = true and false; z = false or true
... = 144
... == !x && y || z
"hello" |> String.upcase |> String.downcase()
{^z, a} = {true, x}

# Free operators (added in 1.0.0)
p  ~>> f  = bind(p, f)
p1 ~>  p2 = pair_right(p1, p2)
p1 <~  p2 = pair_left(p1, p2)
p1 <~> p2 = pair_both(p1, p2)
p  |~> f  = map(p, f)
p1 <|> p2 = either(p1, p2)

# Lists, tuples, maps, keywords
[1, :a, 'hello'] ++ [2, 3]
[:head | [?t, ?a, ?i, ?l]]

{:one, 2.0, "three"}

[...: "this", <<>>: "is", %{}: "a keyword", %: "list", {}: "too"]
["this is an atom too": 1, "so is this": 2]
[option: "value", key: :word]
[++: "operator", ~~~: :&&&]

map = %{shortcut: "syntax"}
%{map | "update" => "me"}
%{ 12 => 13, :weird => ['thing'] }

# Comprehensions
for x <- 1..10, x < 5, do: {x, x}
pixels = "12345678"
for << <<r::4, g::4, b::4, a::size(4)>> <- pixels >> do
  [r, {g, %{"b" => a}}]
end

# String interpolation
"String #{inspect "interpolation"} is quite #{1+4+7} difficult"

# Identifiers
abc_123 = 1
_018OP = 2
A__0 == 3

# Modules
defmodule Long.Module.Name do
  @moduledoc "Simple module docstring"

  @doc """
  Multiline docstring
  "with quotes"
  and #{ inspect %{"interpolation" => "in" <> "action"} }
  now with #{ {:a, 'tuple'} }
  and #{ inspect {
      :tuple,
      %{ with: "nested #{ inspect %{ :interpolation => %{} } }" }
  } }
  """
  defstruct [:a, :name, :height]

  @doc ~S'''
  No #{interpolation} of any kind.
  \000 \x{ff}

  \n #{\x{ff}}
  '''
  def func(a, b \\ []), do: :ok

  # Function
  def f(x), do: x
  # Operator definition (don't highlight the `x`!)
  def x + y, do: nil
  def x * y, do: nil
  def x |> y, do: nil
  def x && y, do: nil
  def x || y, do: nil
  # Word operators
  def x and y, do: nil
  def x or y, do: nil
  def x in y, do: nil
  # unquote, quote and unquote_splicing:
  def quote(f)(x), do: nil
  def unquote(f)(x), do: nil
  def unquote_splicing(f)(x), do: nil
  # function name that starts with `quote`:
  def quote_me(x), do: nil

  @doc false
  def __before_compile__(_) do
    :ok
  end
end

# Structs
defmodule Second.Module do
  s = %Long.Module.Name{name: "Silly"}
  %Long.Module.Name{s | height: {192, :cm}}
  ".. #{%Long.Module.Name{s | height: {192, :cm}}} .."
end

# Types, pseudo-vars, attributes
defmodule M do
  @custom_attr :some_constant

  @before_compile Long.Module.Name

  @typedoc "This is a type"
  @type typ :: integer

  @typedoc """
  Another type
  """
  @opaque typtyp :: 1..10

  @spec func(typ, typtyp) :: :ok | :fail
  def func(a, b) do
    a || b || :ok || :fail
    Path.expand("..", __DIR__)
    IO.inspect __ENV__
    __NOTAPSEUDOVAR__ = 11
    __MODULE__.func(b, a)
  end

  defmacro m() do
    __CALLER__
  end
end

# Functions
anon = fn x, y, z ->
  fn(a, b, c) ->
    &(x + y - z * a / &1 + b + div(&2, c))
  end
end

&Set.put(&1, &2) ; & Set.put(&1, &2) ; &( Set.put(&1, &1) )

# Function calls
anon.(1, 2, 3); self; hd([1,2,3])
Kernel.spawn(fn -> :ok end)
IO.ANSI.black

# Control flow
if :this do
  :that
else
  :otherwise
end

pid = self
receive do
  {:EXIT, _} -> :done
  {^pid, :_} -> nil
  after 100 -> :no_luck
end

case __ENV__.line do
  x when is_integer(x) -> x
  x when x in 1..12 -> -x
end

cond do
  false -> "too bad"
  4 > 5 -> "oops"
  true -> nil
end

# Lexical scope modifiers
import Kernel, except: [spawn: 1, +: 2, /: 2, Unless: 2]
alias Long.Module.Name, as: N0men123_and4
use Bitwise

4 &&& 5
2 <<< 3

# Protocols
defprotocol Useless do
  def func1(this)
  def func2(that)
end

defimpl Useless, for: Atom do
end

# Exceptions
defmodule NotAnError do
  defexception [:message]
end

raise NotAnError, message: "This is not an error"

  ".. #{%Long.Module.Name{s | height: {192, :cm}}} .."
end

# Types, pseudo-vars, attributes
defmodule M do
  @custom_attr :some_constant

  @before_compile Long.Module.Name

  @typedoc "This is a type"
  @type typ :: integer

  @typedoc """
  Another type
  """
  @opaque typtyp :: 1..10

  @spec func(typ, typtyp) :: :ok | :fail
  def func(a, b) do
    a || b || :ok || :fail
    Path.expand("..", __DIR__)
    IO.inspect __ENV__
    __NOTAPSEUDOVAR__ = 11
    __MODULE__.func(b, a)
  end

  defmacro m() do
    __CALLER__
  end
end

# Functions
anon = fn x, y, z ->
  fn(a, b, c) ->
    &(x + y - z * a / &1 + b + div(&2, c))
  end
end

&Set.put(&1, &2) ; & Set.put(&1, &2) ; &( Set.put(&1, &1) )

# Function calls
anon.(1, 2, 3); self; hd([1,2,3])
Kernel.spawn(fn -> :ok end)
IO.ANSI.black

# Control flow
if :this do
  :that
else
  :otherwise
end

pid = self
receive do
  {:EXIT, _} -> :done
  {^pid, :_} -> nil
  after 100 -> :no_luck
end

case __ENV__.line do
  x when is_integer(x) -> x
  x when x in 1..12 -> -x
end

cond do
  false -> "too bad"
  4 > 5 -> "oops"
  true -> nil
end

# Lexical scope modifiers
import Kernel, except: [spawn: 1, +: 2, /: 2, Unless: 2]
alias Long.Module.Name, as: N0men123_and4
use Bitwise

4 &&& 5
2 <<< 3

# Protocols
defprotocol Useless do
  def func1(this)
  def func2(that)
end

defimpl Useless, for: Atom do
end

# Exceptions
defmodule NotAnError do
  defexception [:message]
end

raise NotAnError, message: "This is not an error"

Trac Style (trac)¶

To use this style just require the Makeup.Styles.HTML.StyleMap module and access the trac constant: 

# styles are macros that expand to constants
require Makeup.Styles.HTML.StyleMap
alias Makeup.Styles.HTML.StyleMap
StyleMap.trac_style

Or import the module and use the constant defined there: 

import Makeup.Styles.HTML.StyleMap
trac_style

nesting.exs¶ 

defmodule MyModule do
  @moduledoc """
  This is documentation for the module
  """
  
  @doc """
  This is documentation for the function
  """
  def f(x, y, z) do
    # Place the cursor over the delimiters (...), [...], etc.
    list = [x, y, z]
    tuple = {x, y, z}
    map = %{"x" => x, "y" => y, "z" => z}
    struct = %Long.Module.Name{x: x, y: y, z: y}
    << a::size(x), b::size(y), x::size(z) >> = "abcde"
    # Nested delimiters work too:
    nested = %{
      a: [x, y, z],
      b: {x, {x, y}, {x, {x, y}, {x, y, z, [x, y, z]}}},
      c: %Long.Module.Name{
        x: x,
        y: y,
        z: << a::size(x), b::size(y) >>
      }
    }
  end
  # That's all, folks!

  # The perfectly idiomatic Elixir code below is hard for mere humans to follow.
  # Maybe a little makeup can help you?
  # Place the cursor over the block keywords: do, else, catch, rescue after, end
  def g() do
    IO.inspect do
      "a"
    else
      IO.inspect do
        fn x -> x + 2 end # yes, it works on fn ... end too!
      else
        "b"
      catch
        if c do
          x
        else
          case y do
            1 -> if a do
                   b
                 else
                   c
                 end
            _ -> "Wow, we're deep now!"
          end
        end
      rescue
        "d"
      after
        "e"
      end
      "b"
    after
      "e"
    end
  end
end

sandbox.exs¶ 

# Numbers
0b0101011
1234 ; 0x1A ; 0xbeef ; 0763 ; 0o123
3.14 ; 5.0e21 ; 0.5e-12
100_000_000

# these are not valid numbers
0b012 ; 0xboar ; 0o888
0B01 ; 0XAF ; 0O123

# Characters
?a ; ?1 ; ?\n ; ?\s ; ?\c ; ? ; ?,
?\x{12} ; ?\x{abcd}
?\x34 ; ?\xF

# these show that only the first digit is part of the character
?\123 ; ?\12 ; ?\7

# Atoms
:this ; :that
:'complex atom'
:"with' \"\" 'quotes"
:" multi
 line ' \s \123 \xff
atom"
:... ; :<<>> ; :%{} ; :% ; :{}
:++; :--; :*; :~~~; :::
:% ; :. ; :<-

# Strings
"Hello world"
"Interspersed \x{ff} codes \7 \8 \65 \016 and \t\s\\s\z\+ \\ escapes"
"Quotes ' inside \" \123 the \"\" \xF \\xF string \\\" end"
"Multiline
   string"

# Char lists
'this is a list'
'escapes \' \t \\\''
'Multiline
    char
  list
'

# Binaries
<<1, 2, 3>>
<<"hello"::binary, c :: utf8, x::[4, unit(2)]>> = "helloâ„¢1"

# Sigils
~r/this + i\s "a" regex/
~R'this + i\s "a" regex too'
~w(hello #{ ["has" <> "123", '\c\d', "\123 interpol" | []] } world)s
~W(hello #{no "123" \c\d \123 interpol} world)s

~s{Escapes terminators \{ and \}, but no {balancing} # outside of sigil here }

~S"No escapes \s\t\n and no #{interpolation}"

:"atoms work #{"to" <> "o"}"

# Operators
x = 1 + 2.0 * 3
y = true and false; z = false or true
... = 144
... == !x && y || z
"hello" |> String.upcase |> String.downcase()
{^z, a} = {true, x}

# Free operators (added in 1.0.0)
p  ~>> f  = bind(p, f)
p1 ~>  p2 = pair_right(p1, p2)
p1 <~  p2 = pair_left(p1, p2)
p1 <~> p2 = pair_both(p1, p2)
p  |~> f  = map(p, f)
p1 <|> p2 = either(p1, p2)

# Lists, tuples, maps, keywords
[1, :a, 'hello'] ++ [2, 3]
[:head | [?t, ?a, ?i, ?l]]

{:one, 2.0, "three"}

[...: "this", <<>>: "is", %{}: "a keyword", %: "list", {}: "too"]
["this is an atom too": 1, "so is this": 2]
[option: "value", key: :word]
[++: "operator", ~~~: :&&&]

map = %{shortcut: "syntax"}
%{map | "update" => "me"}
%{ 12 => 13, :weird => ['thing'] }

# Comprehensions
for x <- 1..10, x < 5, do: {x, x}
pixels = "12345678"
for << <<r::4, g::4, b::4, a::size(4)>> <- pixels >> do
  [r, {g, %{"b" => a}}]
end

# String interpolation
"String #{inspect "interpolation"} is quite #{1+4+7} difficult"

# Identifiers
abc_123 = 1
_018OP = 2
A__0 == 3

# Modules
defmodule Long.Module.Name do
  @moduledoc "Simple module docstring"

  @doc """
  Multiline docstring
  "with quotes"
  and #{ inspect %{"interpolation" => "in" <> "action"} }
  now with #{ {:a, 'tuple'} }
  and #{ inspect {
      :tuple,
      %{ with: "nested #{ inspect %{ :interpolation => %{} } }" }
  } }
  """
  defstruct [:a, :name, :height]

  @doc ~S'''
  No #{interpolation} of any kind.
  \000 \x{ff}

  \n #{\x{ff}}
  '''
  def func(a, b \\ []), do: :ok

  # Function
  def f(x), do: x
  # Operator definition (don't highlight the `x`!)
  def x + y, do: nil
  def x * y, do: nil
  def x |> y, do: nil
  def x && y, do: nil
  def x || y, do: nil
  # Word operators
  def x and y, do: nil
  def x or y, do: nil
  def x in y, do: nil
  # unquote, quote and unquote_splicing:
  def quote(f)(x), do: nil
  def unquote(f)(x), do: nil
  def unquote_splicing(f)(x), do: nil
  # function name that starts with `quote`:
  def quote_me(x), do: nil

  @doc false
  def __before_compile__(_) do
    :ok
  end
end

# Structs
defmodule Second.Module do
  s = %Long.Module.Name{name: "Silly"}
  %Long.Module.Name{s | height: {192, :cm}}
  ".. #{%Long.Module.Name{s | height: {192, :cm}}} .."
end

[++: "operator", ~~~: :&&&]

map = %{shortcut: "syntax"}
%{map | "update" => "me"}
%{ 12 => 13, :weird => ['thing'] }

# Comprehensions
for x <- 1..10, x < 5, do: {x, x}
pixels = "12345678"
for << <<r::4, g::4, b::4, a::size(4)>> <- pixels >> do
  [r, {g, %{"b" => a}}]
end

# String interpolation
"String #{inspect "interpolation"} is quite #{1+4+7} difficult"

# Identifiers
abc_123 = 1
_018OP = 2
A__0 == 3

# Modules
defmodule Long.Module.Name do
  @moduledoc "Simple module docstring"

  @doc """
  Multiline docstring
  "with quotes"
  and #{ inspect %{"interpolation" => "in" <> "action"} }
  now with #{ {:a, 'tuple'} }
  and #{ inspect {
      :tuple,
      %{ with: "nested #{ inspect %{ :interpolation => %{} } }" }
  } }
  """
  defstruct [:a, :name, :height]

  @doc ~S'''
  No #{interpolation} of any kind.
  \000 \x{ff}

  \n #{\x{ff}}
  '''
  def func(a, b \\ []), do: :ok

  # Function
  def f(x), do: x
  # Operator definition (don't highlight the `x`!)
  def x + y, do: nil
  def x * y, do: nil
  def x |> y, do: nil
  def x && y, do: nil
  def x || y, do: nil
  # Word operators
  def x and y, do: nil
  def x or y, do: nil
  def x in y, do: nil
  # unquote, quote and unquote_splicing:
  def quote(f)(x), do: nil
  def unquote(f)(x), do: nil
  def unquote_splicing(f)(x), do: nil
  # function name that starts with `quote`:
  def quote_me(x), do: nil

  @doc false
  def __before_compile__(_) do
    :ok
  end
end

# Structs
defmodule Second.Module do
  s = %Long.Module.Name{name: "Silly"}
  %Long.Module.Name{s | height: {192, :cm}}
  ".. #{%Long.Module.Name{s | height: {192, :cm}}} .."
end

# Types, pseudo-vars, attributes
defmodule M do
  @custom_attr :some_constant

  @before_compile Long.Module.Name

  @typedoc "This is a type"
  @type typ :: integer

  @typedoc """
  Another type
  """
  @opaque typtyp :: 1..10

  @spec func(typ, typtyp) :: :ok | :fail
  def func(a, b) do
    a || b || :ok || :fail
    Path.expand("..", __DIR__)
    IO.inspect __ENV__
    __NOTAPSEUDOVAR__ = 11
    __MODULE__.func(b, a)
  end

  defmacro m() do
    __CALLER__
  end
end

# Functions
anon = fn x, y, z ->
  fn(a, b, c) ->
    &(x + y - z * a / &1 + b + div(&2, c))
  end
end

&Set.put(&1, &2) ; & Set.put(&1, &2) ; &( Set.put(&1, &1) )

# Function calls
anon.(1, 2, 3); self; hd([1,2,3])
Kernel.spawn(fn -> :ok end)
IO.ANSI.black

# Control flow
if :this do
  :that
else
  :otherwise
end

pid = self
receive do
  {:EXIT, _} -> :done
  {^pid, :_} -> nil
  after 100 -> :no_luck
end

case __ENV__.line do
  x when is_integer(x) -> x
  x when x in 1..12 -> -x
end

cond do
  false -> "too bad"
  4 > 5 -> "oops"
  true -> nil
end

# Lexical scope modifiers
import Kernel, except: [spawn: 1, +: 2, /: 2, Unless: 2]
alias Long.Module.Name, as: N0men123_and4
use Bitwise

4 &&& 5
2 <<< 3

# Protocols
defprotocol Useless do
  def func1(this)
  def func2(that)
end

defimpl Useless, for: Atom do
end

# Exceptions
defmodule NotAnError do
  defexception [:message]
end

raise NotAnError, message: "This is not an error"

Xcode Style (xcode)¶

To use this style just require the Makeup.Styles.HTML.StyleMap module and access the xcode constant: 

# styles are macros that expand to constants
require Makeup.Styles.HTML.StyleMap
alias Makeup.Styles.HTML.StyleMap
StyleMap.xcode_style

Or import the module and use the constant defined there: 

import Makeup.Styles.HTML.StyleMap
xcode_style

nesting.exs¶ 

defmodule MyModule do
  @moduledoc """
  This is documentation for the module
  """
  
  @doc """
  This is documentation for the function
  """
  def f(x, y, z) do
    # Place the cursor over the delimiters (...), [...], etc.
    list = [x, y, z]
    tuple = {x, y, z}
    map = %{"x" => x, "y" => y, "z" => z}
    struct = %Long.Module.Name{x: x, y: y, z: y}
    << a::size(x), b::size(y), x::size(z) >> = "abcde"
    # Nested delimiters work too:
    nested = %{
      a: [x, y, z],
      b: {x, {x, y}, {x, {x, y}, {x, y, z, [x, y, z]}}},
      c: %Long.Module.Name{
        x: x,
        y: y,
        z: << a::size(x), b::size(y) >>
      }
    }
  end
  # That's all, folks!

  # The perfectly idiomatic Elixir code below is hard for mere humans to follow.
  # Maybe a little makeup can help you?
  # Place the cursor over the block keywords: do, else, catch, rescue after, end
  def g() do
    IO.inspect do
      "a"
    else
      IO.inspect do
        fn x -> x + 2 end # yes, it works on fn ... end too!
      else
        "b"
      catch
        if c do
          x
        else
          case y do
            1 -> if a do
                   b
                 else
                   c
                 end
            _ -> "Wow, we're deep now!"
          end
        end
      rescue
        "d"
      after
        "e"
      end
      "b"
    after
      "e"
    end
  end
end

sandbox.exs¶ 

# Numbers
0b0101011
1234 ; 0x1A ; 0xbeef ; 0763 ; 0o123
3.14 ; 5.0e21 ; 0.5e-12
100_000_000

# these are not valid numbers
0b012 ; 0xboar ; 0o888
0B01 ; 0XAF ; 0O123

# Characters
?a ; ?1 ; ?\n ; ?\s ; ?\c ; ? ; ?,
?\x{12} ; ?\x{abcd}
?\x34 ; ?\xF

# these show that only the first digit is part of the character
?\123 ; ?\12 ; ?\7

# Atoms
:this ; :that
:'complex atom'
:"with' \"\" 'quotes"
:" multi
 line ' \s \123 \xff
atom"
:... ; :<<>> ; :%{} ; :% ; :{}
:++; :--; :*; :~~~; :::
:% ; :. ; :<-

# Strings
"Hello world"
"Interspersed \x{ff} codes \7 \8 \65 \016 and \t\s\\s\z\+ \\ escapes"
"Quotes ' inside \" \123 the \"\" \xF \\xF string \\\" end"
"Multiline
   string"

# Char lists
'this is a list'
'escapes \' \t \\\''
'Multiline
    char
  list
'

# Binaries
<<1, 2, 3>>
<<"hello"::binary, c :: utf8, x::[4, unit(2)]>> = "helloâ„¢1"

# Sigils
~r/this + i\s "a" regex/
~R'this + i\s "a" regex too'
~w(hello #{ ["has" <> "123", '\c\d', "\123 interpol" | []] } world)s
~W(hello #{no "123" \c\d \123 interpol} world)s

~s{Escapes terminators \{ and \}, but no {balancing} # outside of sigil here }

~S"No escapes \s\t\n and no #{interpolation}"

:"atoms work #{"to" <> "o"}"

# Operators
x = 1 + 2.0 * 3
y = true and false; z = false or true
... = 144
... == !x && y || z
"hello" |> String.upcase |> String.downcase()
{^z, a} = {true, x}

# Free operators (added in 1.0.0)
p  ~>> f  = bind(p, f)
p1 ~>  p2 = pair_right(p1, p2)
p1 <~  p2 = pair_left(p1, p2)
p1 <~> p2 = pair_both(p1, p2)
p  |~> f  = map(p, f)
p1 <|> p2 = either(p1, p2)

# Lists, tuples, maps, keywords
[1, :a, 'hello'] ++ [2, 3]
[:head | [?t, ?a, ?i, ?l]]

{:one, 2.0, "three"}

[...: "this", <<>>: "is", %{}: "a keyword", %: "list", {}: "too"]
["this is an atom too": 1, "so is this": 2]
[option: "value", key: :word]
[++: "operator", ~~~: :&&&]

map = %{shortcut: "syntax"}
%{map | "update" => "me"}
%{ 12 => 13, :weird => ['thing'] }
